study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether combining neuromuscular electrical stimulation (NMES) with motor control exercise (MCE) improves lumbar multifidus muscle activation and motor performance in individuals with movement control impairment (MCI).
results_summary: The study found that NMES combined with MCE significantly improved lumbar multifidus activation and motor performance in individuals with MCI compared to MCE alone, though both groups still showed lower activation than healthy controls at baseline.
population_specificity: 25 participants without low back pain and 35 participants with movement control impairment (MCI).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the range of pediatric neurological conditions for which Neuromuscular Electrical Stimulation (NMES) has been studied, excluding cerebral palsy.
results_summary: NMES was well-tolerated in pediatric patients and showed potential to augment traditional therapy methods for improving strength, though outcome measurements were heterogeneous. The study included 35 studies with 353 pediatric participants across various neuromuscular conditions.
population_specificity: Pediatric patients (mean age 7y 4mo, range 1wk-38y) with conditions such as stroke, spinal cord injury, myelomeningocele, scoliosis, congenital clubfoot, obstetric brachial plexus injury, and genetic neuromuscular diseases.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of a novel BCI-FES system versus traditional NMES for motor function recovery in stroke patients.
results_summary: The BCI-FES group showed significantly greater improvements in FMA-UE and Kendall MMT scores compared to the NMES group, suggesting superior efficacy for motor recovery. The study also analyzed EEG-based ERD trends in the BCI-FES group.
population_specificity: 32 patients with chronic stroke.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the effect of neuromuscular electrical stimulation (NMES) on skeletal muscle, biomechanics of movement, functional mobility, strength, spasticity, muscle architecture, and body composition in children and adolescents with chronic neurological disorders and chronic diseases.
results_summary: NMES was effective in improving muscle strength, biomechanics of movement, and functional mobility in children with cerebral palsy, spinal muscular atrophy, and obstetric injury of the brachial plexus. The pooled effect on gross motor functional measure showed a standardized mean difference of 0.41 (95% CI = 0.19-0.64).
population_specificity: Children and adolescents aged 3-14 years with chronic neurological disorders and chronic diseases.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize current research on rehabilitation interventions, including neuromuscular electrical stimulation, for patients recovering from acute decompensated heart failure (ADHF).
results_summary: The study identified that 29% of the reviewed trial protocols focused on neuromuscular electrical stimulation, all employing low-moderate intensity training with outcomes targeting physical function and quality of life. No specific efficacy results for neuromuscular electrical stimulation were detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Patients with acute decompensated heart failure (ADHF) and low ejection fraction (<40%).

study_goal: To assess the acceptability and feasibility of NMES in people with idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF) and determine if a future definitive trial is warranted.
results_summary: The study found that NMES was acceptable to participants, but recruitment challenges made a definitive trial unfeasible. More intervention group participants completed the study and experienced adverse events, while assessor blinding was maintained.
population_specificity: People with idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF), median age 76 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether combining corrective exercises with neuromuscular electrical stimulation (NMES) is more effective than exercises alone in improving clinical and radiological outcomes in children with flexible flatfeet.
results_summary: The study found that the intervention group (corrective exercises + NMES) showed significantly greater improvements in Staheli's arch index, navicular drop, and radiographic indexes compared to the control group (corrective exercises + sham NMES). These improvements were both clinically and statistically significant.
population_specificity: Children aged 7-12 years with flexible flatfeet.
effective_dosage: 3 sessions per week (specific NMES parameters not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of Neuromuscular Electrical Stimulation (NMES) on quadriceps muscle strength and mass in healthy young and older adults.
results_summary: NMES improved quadriceps muscle strength in young adults compared to control groups, though less effectively than voluntary resistance training. Effects on muscle mass were inconclusive in young adults, while limited evidence suggested potential benefits for strength and mass in older adults.
population_specificity: Healthy young and older adults.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effectiveness of rehabilitation interventions, specifically neuromuscular electrical stimulation, in adults with multiple organ dysfunction syndrome.
results_summary: The study found that neuromuscular electrical stimulation showed positive effects on muscle mass preservation compared to no treatment or standard physiotherapy, though the limited evidence prevents firm conclusions.
population_specificity: Critically ill adults with multiple organ dysfunction syndrome, possibly due to COVID-19.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the rehabilitative effectiveness of sequential 4-channel NMES with conventional 2-channel NMES for treating dysphagia.
results_summary: The 4-channel NMES group showed significant improvement in multiple dysphagia-related scales (VDS, PAS, FOIS, MDADI), while the 2-channel NMES group improved in some but not all measures. The 4-channel NMES outperformed the 2-channel NMES in oral and total VDS scores.
population_specificity: 26 subjects with dysphagia (12 in 4-channel NMES group, 11 in 2-channel NMES group).
effective_dosage: 2- or 4-channel NMES for 300-800 minutes total, minimal session: 7 times.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of long-term versus short-term use of neuromuscular electrical stimulation (NMES) in postoperative rehabilitation following ACL reconstruction.
results_summary: The study found that long-term use of NMES appears more beneficial than short-term use in ACL rehabilitation, though specific benefits were not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing postoperative rehabilitation following anterior cruciate ligament reconstruction (ACLR).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether combining transcranial direct current stimulation with neuromuscular electrical stimulation improves upper extremity motor function in chronic stroke patients compared to conventional rehabilitation alone.
results_summary: The combined treatment group showed significant improvement in Fugl-Meyer Assessment upper extremity scores and Action Research Arm Test results compared to other groups, with benefits sustained at 1-month follow-up.
population_specificity: Chronic stroke patients (onset >6 months prior)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review and synthesize current literature on managing refractory pain after total joint replacement, including the effectiveness of Neuromuscular Electrical Stimulation (NMES).
results_summary: The study found that NMES, along with other modalities, demonstrated effectiveness in improving pain and functional outcomes in patients with chronic pain after total knee replacement, based on meta-analyses and case reports.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic pain after total knee replacement (TKA).

study_goal: To systematically review and evaluate the effectiveness of electrical stimulation (e.g., TENS) in improving clinical outcomes such as pain reduction, range of motion, and functional recovery after hip fractures.
results_summary: Electrical stimulation (e.g., TENS) reduced pain and improved range of motion and functional recovery after hip fractures, but conclusive evidence on muscle strength improvement was lacking. The review highlights the need for more high-quality trials in this area.
population_specificity: Patients recovering from hip fracture surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of two NMES protocols (50 Hz and 35 Hz) on upper limb motor impairment and function in older adults with spastic hemiparesis after stroke.
results_summary: Both NMES protocols showed significant improvements in range of motion, grip and pinch strength, Modified Ashworth Scale, and muscle electrical activity in wrist extensors. The 35 Hz NMES intervention also significantly improved the Barthel Index, though no differences were found between groups in the Box and Block Test.
population_specificity: Older adults with spastic hemiparesis after stroke.
effective_dosage: NMES at 50 Hz and 35 Hz (frequency not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if intradialytic NMES could attenuate leg lean mass loss and improve phase angle in hemodialysis patients.
results_summary: NMES improved phase angle but did not significantly change leg lean mass compared to the control group. The phase angle increase was statistically significant (p = 0.004).
population_specificity: 21 adult hemodialysis patients (8 female, 13 male; mean age 45.8 ± 10.6 years).
effective_dosage: 40 minutes per session, applied bilaterally at quadriceps or gastrocnemius muscles during each hemodialysis session (3 times per week).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the feasibility and preliminary efficacy of a personalized intervention combining robotics, virtual reality, and NMES for improving upper extremity function in individuals with moderate/severe stroke.
results_summary: The study found that 64% of participants showed clinically meaningful improvements in upper extremity function, suggesting the personalized approach (including NMES for those with good hand recovery potential) may be beneficial.
population_specificity: Individuals with moderate to severe upper extremity impairments due to chronic stroke (n=28).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the influence of different electrical stimulation currents (KFAC and PC) and phase durations (200 µs and 500 µs) on torque, efficiency, and discomfort in neuromuscular electrical stimulation.
results_summary: The study found that wider phase durations (500 µs) produced significantly higher torque and current efficiency but also greater discomfort compared to narrow phase durations (200 µs). Both KFAC and PC currents with the same phase duration induced similar torque, efficiency, and discomfort levels.
population_specificity: 24 healthy male participants (age 22.3 ± 3.5 years).
effective_dosage: Stimulation intensity increments of 10 mA, with submaximal relative torque (e.g., 40% MVC) achieved at ~60% and ~80% of maximal current intensity for 500 µs and 200 µs, respectively.
study_duration: Sessions with a minimum of seven days between interventions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of synchronized Neuromuscular Electrical Stimulation (NMES) on submental muscles during ingestion of soft food in stroke patients with mild-to-moderate dysphagia.
results_summary: Synchronized NMES improved swallowing function (measured by DOSS scores) and reduced food aspiration risk in stroke patients with dysphagia, showing significant differences compared to conventional and eating training groups. The IST group had fewer cases of Stroke-Associated Pneumonia and wet voice post-treatment.
population_specificity: 83 patients with mild-to-moderate dysphagia following stroke.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether NMES could maintain calf muscle cross-sectional area volume and improve patient-reported outcomes following Achilles tendon surgery.
results_summary: The study found that NMES was associated with accelerated recovery and pain reduction, though specific comparative results between the active and sham groups were not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: 40 patients (23 male, 17 female) with a mean age of 48.9 years who underwent Achilles tendon repair.
effective_dosage: Not specified (4-lead NMES device used, but exact stimulation parameters not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of traditional swallowing therapy versus a combined therapy including neuromuscular electrical stimulation in stroke patients with chronic oropharyngeal dysphagia.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences between the two groups in posterior oral spillage time, whiteout time, or functional oral intake scale. However, the group receiving neuromuscular electrical stimulation showed significant improvement in visual analog scale scores, though both groups demonstrated overall improvement.
population_specificity: Eight patients with chronic oropharyngeal dysphagia after stroke.

study_goal: To evaluate the effects of a rehabilitation program combining pelvic floor muscle training and neuromuscular electrical stimulation for postpartum lumbopelvic pain.
results_summary: The intervention group showed significant improvements in pain (NPRS), disability (MODQ), and physical quality of life (SF-36) compared to the control group, but no significant improvement in mental quality of life.
population_specificity: Women with lumbopelvic pain 3 months postpartum.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the evidence, guidelines, and benefits of using Neuromuscular Electrical Stimulation (NMES) for ICU patients, particularly those with COVID-19, and provide practical recommendations for its use in rehabilitation.
results_summary: The study found that NMES can prevent muscle atrophy, improve muscle strength and function, maintain blood flow, and reduce edema, potentially aiding in ventilator weaning and long-term recovery for COVID-19 patients. Evidence suggests NMES may be suitable for rehabilitation pathways, though practical and safety considerations must be addressed.
population_specificity: Patients admitted to the intensive care unit, particularly those with COVID-19 and ICU-acquired weakness.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether combining neuromuscular electrical stimulation (NMES) with branched-chain amino acids (BCAA) therapy improves skeletal muscle mass and strength in post-living donor liver transplantation (LDLT) patients compared to NMES alone.
results_summary: The study is designed to evaluate changes in skeletal muscle mass and quadriceps strength over 3 months, but results are not yet reported as the abstract describes a planned trial. The expected outcome is evidence supporting the combined therapy's benefits for muscle preservation in post-LDLT patients.
population_specificity: Patients with decompensated cirrhosis after living donor liver transplantation (LDLT).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the clinical benefits and adverse events of different intradialytic exercise modalities, including Neuromuscular Electrical Stimulation, in end-stage renal disease patients undergoing hemodialysis.
results_summary: Suggestive evidence was found for associations between intradialytic exercise (including combined exercise) and improved functional capacity, physical, and psychosocial variables, with few or no adverse events reported.
population_specificity: Patients with end-stage renal disease undergoing hemodialysis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess whether neuromuscular electrical stimulation (NMES) could accelerate recovery of physical function in patients after coronary artery bypass graft surgery before starting cardiac rehabilitation.
results_summary: NMES led to greater improvements in 6-minute walk test distance and power output compared to controls, indicating enhanced physical function recovery post-surgery. Overall, physical function improved significantly in the entire cohort, but NMES provided additional benefits.
population_specificity: Patients who underwent coronary artery bypass graft surgery.
effective_dosage: Bilateral NMES applied to quadriceps muscles, 5 days per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare fatigue and discomfort levels between pulsed current (PC) and alternating current (AC) during a submaximal contraction protocol in healthy individuals.
results_summary: AC at 2.5 kHz caused higher fatigue, greater torque decline, and fewer contractions to reach 50% torque decline compared to PC, though discomfort levels were similar between currents. PC was found to be less fatigable and more effective for generating muscle work and mechanical load.
population_specificity: 30 healthy male volunteers (mean age 23.23 years, SD = 4.59).
effective_dosage: PC (pulse duration = 2 ms, frequency = 100 Hz); AC (2.5 kHz, pulse duration = 0.4 ms, burst frequency = 100 Hz).
study_duration: 20 minutes per session (80 contractions, 5:10 seconds on:off), with a 7-day interval between protocols.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the potential benefits, risks, and concerns of Neuromuscular Electrical Stimulation (NMES) for managing dysphagia and Temporo-Mandibular Joint Disorder (TMD).
results_summary: The abstract highlights NMES as an innovative therapeutic modality for dysphagia and TMD, suggesting its potential benefits but also noting the need for caution due to limited evidence-based literature. It emphasizes an interdisciplinary approach combining dentistry and speech therapy.
population_specificity: Patients with oro-pharyngeal dysphagia and Temporo-Mandibular Joint Disorder (TMD).

study_goal: To investigate the effect of neuromuscular electrical stimulation (NMES) parameters on quadriceps strength recovery after knee surgery.
results_summary: The study found grade B evidence supporting NMES for quadriceps strength recovery post-knee surgery, recommending specific parameters (≥50 Hz, maximum tolerable intensity, biphasic current, large electrodes, and a 1:2 to 1:3 duty cycle ratio) for optimal effects. However, evidence was inconsistent across studies.
population_specificity: Patients recovering from knee surgery.
effective_dosage: Frequency ≥50 Hz, maximum tolerable intensity, biphasic current, large electrodes, duty cycle ratio of 1:2 to 1:3.

study_goal: The researchers sought to evaluate the effect of neuromuscular or functional electrical stimulation on the duration of invasive mechanical ventilation in critically ill subjects.
results_summary: Neuromuscular or functional electrical stimulation may slightly reduce the duration of invasive mechanical ventilation, but the quality of evidence is low to very low, and results are uncertain for subjects with COPD compared to usual care or placebo. More RCTs with better methodological design are needed.
population_specificity: Critically ill subjects, including those with COPD.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the use of mechanomyographic (MMG) signals for assessing muscle performance under neuromuscular electrical stimulation (NMES) and review its reliability and clinical applications.
results_summary: The review found that MMG through NMES provides reliable feature factors for muscle activity assessment, though signal fluctuations and processing speed requirements introduce potential errors. Few studies have explored machine learning as an alternative to statistical analysis for assessing muscle fatigue, torque, and force.
population_specificity: Not specified (review of existing studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the potential of neuromuscular electrical stimulation as a therapeutic option for addressing brain-derived neurotrophic factor (BDNF) deficiency in rheumatoid arthritis patients.
results_summary: The abstract suggests that neuromuscular electrical stimulation is proposed as an attractive therapeutic option for addressing BDNF deficiency in RA, but specific efficacy results are not detailed. The study highlights possible mechanisms linking RA and BDNF deficiency but does not provide concrete outcomes from the intervention.
population_specificity: Rheumatoid arthritis patients with potential neuropsychiatric troubles, including depression and cognitive dysfunction.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of an EMG-driven exoneuromusculoskeleton integrating NMES for upper limb rehabilitation in stroke patients.
results_summary: The system assisted elbow, wrist, and finger movements during arm tasks under voluntary control, with quantified pressure/torque properties and demonstrated assistive capability in chronic stroke patients.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic stroke

study_goal: To investigate the effect of Neuromuscular Electrical Stimulation (NMES) on muscle thickness, strength, and morphological/molecular markers in critically ill patients.
results_summary: NMES attenuated muscle thickness loss in the stimulated leg compared to the non-stimulated leg but did not affect strength. Preservation of muscle mass was more likely in patients receiving opioids, those with minimal muscle contraction during NMES, and those prone to muscle loss. Stimulated muscles showed larger myofibers and higher MyHC-I gene expression.
population_specificity: Adult critically ill patients with an expected prolonged stay.
interactions: Opioid administration was associated with better muscle thickness preservation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of reciprocal neuromuscular electrical stimulation (rNMES) alone and in combination with botulinum neurotoxin-A (BoNT-A) on upper extremity function in children with spastic hemiplegia.
results_summary: The study found that combining rNMES with BoNT-A resulted in greater improvement in upper-limb function compared to either treatment alone, with sustained benefits at 6-month follow-up.
population_specificity: Children aged 6-10 years with spastic hemiplegia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of an early rehabilitation program, including neuromuscular electrical stimulation, on muscle strength in COVID-19 patients with acute respiratory distress syndrome in the ICU.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in hand grip or manual muscle strength between the rehab and non-rehab groups post-discharge. The rehab group had a higher prevalence of chronic pulmonary and neurologic diseases, which may have influenced outcomes, but the intervention was deemed safe.
population_specificity: Thirty-five patients with acute respiratory distress syndrome secondary to COVID-19 in an ICU setting.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether adding mirror therapy (MT) to exercise training and neuromuscular electrical stimulation (NMES) improves clinical measurements, mobility, and functionality in people with multiple sclerosis (MS) and unilateral drop foot.
results_summary: The study found that the MT group showed significantly greater improvements in range of motion, muscle strength, proprioception, walking duration, step test duration, and functional scales compared to the control group after 6 weeks, with benefits maintained at 12 weeks.
population_specificity: Ambulatory people with multiple sclerosis and unilateral drop foot.
effective_dosage: NMES was applied 3 days a week at the hospital, combined with an exercise program 2 days a week at home.
study_duration: 6 weeks of combined treatment, followed by 6 weeks of exercise-only intervention (total 12 weeks).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the immediate effects of different Belt electrode skeletal muscle electrical stimulation (B-SES) modes on lower limb muscle flexibility before clinical application.
results_summary: Metabolic B-SES significantly improved sit-and-reach distance compared to pre-intervention and control, suggesting immediate enhancement of lower limb flexibility. No significant effects were observed with Disuse B-SES or control conditions.
population_specificity: 10 healthy subjects
study_duration: Immediate effects assessed (single session per condition)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of Neuromuscular Electrical Stimulation (NMES) compared to other rehabilitation approaches in improving work efficiency in military personnel with knee injuries.
results_summary: NMES improved gross work efficiency by 24%, outperforming standard rehabilitation (12%) and walking with a weighted vest (19%), with the combined NMES/Walk group showing the greatest improvement (40%). All intervention groups demonstrated better submaximal exercise efficiency than standard rehabilitation.
population_specificity: Active duty military service members aged 18-50 with knee injuries.
effective_dosage: NMES was applied to the quadriceps muscle four times per week for 30 minutes (15 minutes per leg), consisting of 15 contractions per leg.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the dosing effect of Neuromuscular Electrical Stimulation (NMES) on femoral vein blood flow, clinical severity, and quality of life in patients with chronic venous disease (CVD).
results_summary: NMES significantly increased femoral vein blood flow (TAMV) in both treatment groups (30 and 60 minutes daily). The 60-minute group also showed improved clinical severity scores and quality of life, while the control group worsened.
population_specificity: 76 patients with chronic venous disease (CEAP C3-C5), mean age 60.8, 47 male and 29 female.
effective_dosage: Group B: 30 minutes NMES daily; Group C: 60 minutes NMES daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if NMES combined with high-protein supplementation could preserve neuromotor and cognitive function in SAH survivors compared to standard care.
results_summary: NMES + HPRO reduced muscle atrophy (6.5% vs 12.5%) and improved functional outcomes (SPPB and mRS scores) at 90 days post-SAH compared to standard care. No serious adverse events were reported.
population_specificity: Aneurysmal subarachnoid hemorrhage survivors with Hunt Hess grade >1, modified Fisher score >1, and BMI <40 kg/m².
effective_dosage: Protein intake of 1.5 ± 0.5 g/kg/day (HPRO group) vs 0.9 ± 0.4 g/kg/day (SOC group). NMES session frequency not specified.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the scientific evidence for early strength interventions, including neuromuscular electrical stimulation, to prevent functional decline in hospitalized elderly COVID-19 patients.
results_summary: The study reviewed evidence supporting neuromuscular electrical stimulation as a strategy to reduce muscle weakness during hospitalization, emphasizing the need for early and safe functional interventions for older adults affected by COVID-19.
population_specificity: Elderly patients hospitalized with COVID-19 experiencing muscle mass and strength loss.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether adding neuromuscular electrical stimulation (NMES) to endurance and resistance training improves exercise tolerance and balance in COPD patients.
results_summary: The study compared the effects of ET + RT + NMES versus ET + RT alone, but the abstract does not provide specific outcome data regarding NMES's effectiveness.
population_specificity: 42 COPD patients.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of Neuromuscular Electrical Stimulation in ameliorating negative changes in muscle function and quantity in hospitalized older adults.
results_summary: The study found limited evidence for the effectiveness of Neuromuscular Electrical Stimulation, with inconsistencies in effect sizes across studies and overall concerns for risk of bias. The strongest evidence was for multi-component physical activity interventions, not Neuromuscular Electrical Stimulation.
population_specificity: Hospitalized older adults (mean age 79.1).

study_goal: The study aimed to summarize factors influencing the efficacy of nutritional interventions on muscle mass in older adults, excluding neuromuscular electrical stimulation.
results_summary: The study did not assess neuromuscular electrical stimulation, as it was an exclusion criterion. The focus was on nutritional interventions like amino acids, creatine, and protein supplements.
population_specificity: Older adults (mean age 78.1 years) without neuromuscular disorders, chronic kidney disease, cancer, or other specified exclusions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of Dry Needling (DN) versus Dry Needling with Intramuscular Electrical Stimulation (DN/IMES) in improving pain and disability in Myofascial Pain Syndrome (MPS).
results_summary: Both DN and DN/IMES significantly improved pain and disability over 6 weeks, with DN/IMES showing earlier pain relief (within 3 weeks). No significant differences between groups were found at 6 or 12 weeks, and improvements were maintained but did not progress further after week 6.
population_specificity: 45 subjects with Myofascial Pain Syndrome (MPS).
study_duration: 6 weeks of intervention, with follow-up to week 12.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether combining Neuromuscular Electrical Stimulation (NMES) with eccentric exercise (ECC) could restore quadriceps strength, improve biomechanical symmetry, and maintain cartilage health after anterior cruciate ligament reconstruction (ACLR).
results_summary: The study is ongoing, but the abstract suggests that NMES combined with ECC may significantly improve strength recovery and biomechanical symmetry at 9 and 18 months post-ACLR, potentially preventing cartilage deterioration. Secondary outcomes include improvements in quadriceps activation, muscle morphology, and patient-reported function.
population_specificity: Participants aged 14-45 years with anterior cruciate ligament rupture.
effective_dosage: NMES delivered 2 times per week for 8 weeks, followed by ECC 2 times per week for 8 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically review the literature to investigate the effects of electrical stimulation, including NMES, in treating dysphonia.
results_summary: The study found that electrical stimulation had a therapeutic effect on various aspects of dysphonia, but due to high risk of bias and heterogeneity among studies, definitive conclusions on its effectiveness could not be made.
population_specificity: Patients with dysphonia caused by vocal fold paralysis, spasmodic dysphonia, behavioral dysphonia, and vocal fold nodules.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the feasibility and effectiveness of a custom, digitally-controlled NMES system for improving knee extension during gait in individuals with cerebral palsy.
results_summary: The NMES system demonstrated low latency (16.5 ± 13.5 ms) and improved mean peak knee extension during mid-stance and total knee excursion in the more affected leg when applied to the vastus lateralis and rectus femoris during stance. The study suggests that precisely timed NMES delivery to quadriceps is a promising treatment for crouch gait.
population_specificity: 15-year-old male with bilateral spastic CP, GMFCS Level III.
effective_dosage: Not specified (stimulation parameters were digitally set but exact values not provided).
study_duration: Single session with four walking conditions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of neuromuscular electrical stimulation (NMES) combined with peripheral muscle training (PMT) against other inspiratory muscle training (IMT) methods on respiratory functions, exercise capacity, and biochemistry parameters in coronary artery disease patients with metabolic syndrome.
results_summary: The NMES + PMT group showed significant improvements in maximal inspiratory pressure and erythrocyte sedimentation rate compared to other groups, alongside overall enhancements in respiratory functions, exercise capacity, and biochemistry markers across all groups.
population_specificity: 60 patients with stable coronary artery disease and metabolic syndrome (NYHA Class I-II, left ventricular ejection fraction >40%).
effective_dosage: NMES was applied to the rectus abdominis (specific dosage not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether a hybrid training system (HTS) combining neuromuscular electrical stimulation with treadmill walking improves insulin resistance and reduces serum IL-6 and SeP levels in patients with NAFLD.
results_summary: The HTS group showed significant reductions in HOMA-IR (insulin resistance), serum IL-6, and SeP levels compared to the control group, suggesting HTS effectively improves insulin resistance by modulating these biomarkers.
population_specificity: Patients with nonalcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) (median age 45, male/female ratio 5/4 in HTS group, 6/3 in control group).
effective_dosage: 30 minutes per session, three times a week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effects of short interphase intervals (IPIs) on the strength of electrically induced isometric contractions (EIC), discomfort, and sensory and motor thresholds in wrist extensor muscles at the highest tolerated current intensity.
results_summary: The study found that IPIs at maximally tolerated current intensity did not increase EIC strength, reduce discomfort, or affect sensory and motor thresholds, contradicting previous studies that showed stronger contractions with IPIs at submaximal intensities. These results were independent of phase durations.
population_specificity: 18 subjects with a mean age of 25.5 years (SD ± 3.97).
effective_dosage: Monophasic pulses (200 µs phase duration) and biphasic pulses (200 or 500 µs phase durations) with/without a 200 µs IPI, at maximum tolerated current intensity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether neuromuscular electrical stimulation (NMES) of the common peroneal nerve increases microvascular blood flow in the wound bed and edge of arterial leg ulcers.
results_summary: NMES significantly increased blood flow (flux) and pulsatility in both the wound bed and edge in all 8 patients, suggesting immediate improvement in microcirculation for ischemic lower limb wounds.
population_specificity: Eight patients with ischemic lower limb wounds.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of neuromuscular electrical stimulation (NMES) on swallowing function in dysphagic stroke patients based on the latest scientific evidence.
results_summary: The review found that NMES combined with traditional swallowing therapy could be an effective intervention to improve swallowing function in stroke patients, with evidence quality graded from moderate to high. Eleven RCTs involving 784 patients supported these findings.
population_specificity: Dysphagic stroke patients in rehabilitation settings.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of neuromuscular electrical stimulation on balance, motor function, and functional capacity in stroke patients.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in postural assessment and movement rehabilitation scores in the neuromuscular electrical stimulation group compared to the control group, though other measures did not show statistically significant differences.
population_specificity: Sixty patients with stroke.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether postoperative NMES use in TKA patients increases quadriceps strength and improves functional outcomes.
results_summary: The abstract suggests NMES may be effective for quadriceps strengthening and attenuating muscle loss post-TKA, but full results are not detailed.
population_specificity: 66 primary total knee arthroplasty (TKA) patients at a large academic medical center.

study_goal: To determine whether early use of NMES can preserve quadriceps muscle size and contractile function at the cellular level in patients undergoing ACL reconstruction.
results_summary: Early NMES use reduced skeletal muscle fiber atrophy in MHC II fibers and preserved contractility in MHC I fibers, demonstrating beneficial modifications to skeletal muscle maladaptations post-ACLR.
population_specificity: Patients (n=25; 12 men/13 women) with acute, first-time ACL rupture.
study_duration: Started soon after injury and maintained through 3 weeks after surgery

study_goal: The researchers aimed to highlight the potential benefits of neuromuscular electrical stimulation (NMES) in counteracting muscle mass loss in older ICU patients.
results_summary: The abstract suggests that NMES, along with physical therapy and early mobilization, may be beneficial for improving muscle mass and function in ICU patients, though specific efficacy data are not detailed.
population_specificity: Older ICU patients with critical illness and muscle mass loss.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the acute effects of Neuromuscular Electrical Stimulation (NMES) combined with varying degrees of Blood Flow Restriction (BFR) on muscular strength, size, and perceptual responses using research-recommended procedures.
results_summary: NMES combined with 80% BFR caused greater acute force decline and increased muscle thickness compared to other conditions, but also resulted in higher pain and perceived exertion ratings. No cardiovascular effects were observed across conditions.
population_specificity: 20 healthy adults (age 27 ± 4 years, height 177 ± 8 cm, body mass 77 ± 13 kg).
effective_dosage: NMES alone, NMES with 40% BFR, NMES with 60% BFR, and NMES with 80% BFR.
study_duration: Six sessions separated by at least 7 days, with experimental conditions performed in the final 4 sessions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the effectiveness of various dysphagia treatments, including Neuromuscular Electrical Stimulation, in Parkinson's disease patients.
results_summary: The review found that several rehabilitative therapies, including Neuromuscular Electrical Stimulation, showed success in improving degenerative function, quality of life, and social relationships in PD patients, but further well-designed randomized controlled studies are needed.
population_specificity: Parkinson's disease patients with oropharyngeal dysphagia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a respiratory rehabilitation program (RRP) including neuromuscular electrical stimulation in promoting functional recovery in a severe COVID-19 ARDS patient.
results_summary: The study found that neuromuscular electrical stimulation, as part of an RRP, contributed to improved muscle function (13% quadriceps size enlargement, MRC score increase from 48/60 to 58/60) and respiratory strength (7% increase), leading to successful weaning from mechanical ventilation and recovery of walking capacity.
population_specificity: A 51-year-old man with severe COVID-19 ARDS, tracheostomized and ventilated, exhibiting ICU-acquired weakness.
study_duration: Duration of the RRP in isolation was one week, followed by continuation in a standard department (total duration not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether neuromuscular electrical stimulation combined with protein supplementation (NMES+PRO) could preserve thigh lean tissue and attenuate insulin resistance during bed rest in older adults.
results_summary: The study found that NMES+PRO preserved thigh lean tissue in healthy older adults during bed rest and suggested a potential role in mitigating insulin resistance, possibly through macrophage polarization.
population_specificity: Healthy older adults aged 60-80 years with a body mass index < 30 kg/m².

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the feasibility and effectiveness of a novel strength training intervention involving neuromuscular electrical stimulation (NMES) compared to conventional strength training in improving muscle strength and health-related quality of life in head and neck cancer survivors.
results_summary: The study found that NMES combined with eccentric overloaded strength training led to significant improvements in maximal muscle strength (19% increase), muscle cross-sectional area (18% improvement), cycling exercise time (18% improvement), and clinically relevant enhancements in health-related quality of life and fatigue.
population_specificity: Head and neck cancer survivors post-treatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Neuromuscular Electrical Stimulation (NMES) could serve as a surrogate for classic exercise by eliciting an exercise training response in skeletal muscle of women with breast cancer undergoing chemotherapy.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results, but the study examined NMES as a potential exercise alternative for breast cancer patients during chemotherapy.
population_specificity: Women diagnosed with breast cancer undergoing chemotherapy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of Neuromuscular Electrical Stimulation (NMES) on exercise capacity, functional performance, symptoms, and health-related quality of life in COPD patients.
results_summary: NMES improved exercise capacity (6MWD) and reduced dyspnea and leg fatigue symptoms but did not significantly affect VO2 peak, peak power, or SGRQ. It was not recommended as an effective alternative training modality for stable COPD patients.
population_specificity: Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) patients

study_goal: The abstract does not specify a study goal related to Neuromuscular Electrical Stimulation.
results_summary: The abstract does not report any findings related to Neuromuscular Electrical Stimulation.
population_specificity: Patients with COPD (chronic obstructive pulmonary disease).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically review the efficacy of electrical stimulation, including neuromuscular electrical stimulation (NMES), for improving walking impairment in patients with lower extremity peripheral artery disease (PAD).
results_summary: The review identified five studies, with only two being randomized controlled trials, and noted trial heterogeneity prevented meta-analysis. NMES was one of three electrical stimulation types used, but the abstract does not specify its individual efficacy results.
population_specificity: Patients with lower extremity peripheral artery disease (PAD) experiencing walking impairment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of various interventions, including exercise training and pharmacological management, in improving objectively-assessed physical activity in people with COPD.
results_summary: The study found that improvements in physical activity were not systematically demonstrated for any particular intervention, though some evidence supported exercise training, physical activity counseling, and pharmacological management. Results were often confined to single studies, and long-term effects were unclear.
population_specificity: People with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD)
study_duration: Varied by intervention (e.g., 3-4 weeks for pharmacological treatment, 6 months for physical activity counseling)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the impact of neuromuscular electrical stimulation and other rehabilitation interventions on clinical outcomes in critically ill adults.
results_summary: Neuromuscular electrical stimulation did not influence mortality but was found to be safe with no serious adverse events reported. The study noted that protocolized physical rehabilitation, not neuromuscular electrical stimulation alone, significantly reduced mechanical ventilation duration and ICU stay.
population_specificity: Critically ill adults in ICU settings.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether NMES during hemodialysis improves functional capacity, muscle strength, and other outcomes in end-stage renal disease patients, while assessing safety.
results_summary: NMES improved functional capacity (6-minute walk distance, peak workload) and muscle strength (knee extensor, handgrip), with no major adverse events. No clear benefits were found for muscle mass, cardiovascular outcomes, or biochemical variables.
population_specificity: Patients receiving hemodialysis for end-stage renal disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of transcutaneous neuromuscular electrical stimulation (NMES) on swallowing disorders compared to traditional therapy alone.
results_summary: The study found a moderate pooled effect size for NMES combined with traditional therapy, with varying effectiveness based on muscle group stimulation (infrahyoid showed large effects, suprahyoid showed negative effects). The quality of evidence was rated as low to very low, indicating insufficient firm evidence to conclude efficacy.
population_specificity: Patients with swallowing disorders.
effective_dosage: Stimulation lasting 45 minutes or less showed a large, significant effect.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the efficacy of neuromuscular electrical stimulation (NMES) in improving muscle strength and reducing pain in patients with knee osteoarthritis and to establish standardized clinical treatment parameters.
results_summary: The review found that NMES is the most effective electrical stimulation treatment for knee osteoarthritis, especially when combined with a strengthening program. Optimal treatment parameters include a frequency of 50-75 Hz, pulse duration of 200-400 μs, and a treatment duration of 20 minutes.
population_specificity: Adult patients with knee osteoarthritis.
effective_dosage: Frequency of 50-75 Hz, pulse duration of 200-400 μs.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of different electrical stimulation treatments (NMES, TENS, or combined NMES/TENS) alongside a home exercise program (HEP) in improving strength, functional performance, and reducing pain in military service members with PFPS.
results_summary: All electrical stimulation groups showed greater improvement in knee extension strength compared to HEP alone, with NMES and NMES/TENS also improving knee flexion strength. Pain improved across all groups without significant differences, and stimulation groups performed better in the 6-minute walk test.
population_specificity: Active duty military members diagnosed with patellofemoral pain syndrome (PFPS).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of different methods of neuromuscular electrical stimulation (contralaterally controlled functional electrical stimulation vs. cyclic neuromuscular electrical stimulation) on upper limb rehabilitation in poststroke patients.
results_summary: The study found no significant between-group differences in hand dexterity (Box and Blocks Test), but arm + hand contralaterally controlled functional electrical stimulation improved reachable workspace and Upper Extremity Fugl-Meyer scores more than other methods. However, these benefits may not translate to noticeable improvements in daily living activities.
population_specificity: 67 participants less than 2 years poststroke.
effective_dosage: 10 sessions/week of assigned electrical stimulation at home plus 24 sessions of functional task practice in the laboratory.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore design considerations for effective neuromuscular electrical stimulation exercise prescription in cancer rehabilitation, integrating exercise training principles and current NMES technologies.
results_summary: The study suggests that individually prescribed concurrent low and high frequency NMES may optimize physical function in cancer patients, and identifies appropriate stimulation parameters for effective application in rehabilitation.
population_specificity: Individuals with cancer undergoing rehabilitation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the state of hybrid NMES-robotic systems for restoring upper limb function in individuals with spinal cord injuries and identify future directions for improvement.
results_summary: The study found that combining NMES with robotic support systems improves accuracy and repeatability in limb positioning but faces challenges in wearability and usability outside clinical settings. Future advancements should focus on better integration, standardized performance reporting, and improved user interfaces.
population_specificity: Individuals with tetraplegia due to cervical-level spinal cord injuries.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether early rehabilitation interventions, including Neuromuscular Electrical Stimulation (NMES), reduce the incidence of Intensive Care Unit-Acquired Weakness (ICUAW) in critically ill patients compared to usual care.
results_summary: Early rehabilitation, including NMES, was associated with a decreased likelihood of developing ICUAW, with odds ratios of 0.63 (screened population) and 0.71 (randomized population). The findings support the use of early rehabilitation in the ICU, though wider confidence intervals suggest the need for further validation.
population_specificity: Critically ill adults in the intensive care unit.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects and safety of percutaneous neuromuscular electrical stimulation (PNMES) for treating neck pain in patients with cervical spondylosis.
results_summary: PNMES significantly reduced neck pain (VAS and NDI scores) and improved cervical range of motion compared to sham treatment, with no adverse events reported in either group.
population_specificity: 124 patients with neck pain from cervical spondylosis at a hospital in Yan'an, China.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the feasibility of using a novel neuromuscular electrical stimulation (NMES) device for deep vein thrombosis (DVT) prevention in patients recovering from elective hip replacement surgery.
results_summary: The NMES group showed no cases of DVT, reduced leg volume, and better hemodynamic responses and TUG scores compared to the compression stockings group, which had two asymptomatic DVT cases. No differences were observed in sit-to-stand scores or hip range of motion.
population_specificity: Patients recovering from elective total hip replacement surgery (n=28).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the impact of neuromuscular electrical stimulation (NMES) on ICU-acquired weakness, focusing on its preventive and therapeutic potential.
results_summary: The study found inconsistent results regarding NMES's effectiveness, with recent systematic reviews and meta-analyses indicating no or only low-quality evidence for its benefit in managing ICU-acquired weakness.
population_specificity: Critically ill patients with ICU-acquired weakness (neuropathy, myopathy, or neuromyopathy).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of rehabilitation interventions, including neuromuscular electrical stimulation, on physical function and immobility-related complications in severe stroke patients.
results_summary: The study found moderate-quality evidence supporting short-term benefits of wrist and finger neuromuscular electrical stimulation in improving wrist extensor and grip strength. However, the overall evidence for rehabilitation interventions, including neuromuscular electrical stimulation, was limited by low study quality and small sample sizes.
population_specificity: Severe stroke patients (mean age 72.7 years, 49.3% males).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of combining neuromuscular electrical stimulation (NMES) and shortwave diathermy (SWD) therapy for treating chronic Bell palsy.
results_summary: The study found that NMES+SWD improved symmetry of voluntary movements and zygomatic muscle movement, but not resting symmetry, compared to exercise alone. No adverse events were reported in either group.
population_specificity: 20 patients with chronic Bell palsy who had undergone 5 months of conventional therapy without recovery.
effective_dosage: 30 minutes per session, 5 sessions per week for 4 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize evidence on the use of neuromuscular electrical stimulation (NMES) for improving diabetic foot ulceration (DFU) healing.
results_summary: Two studies showed improvements in chronic ulcer healing with NMES, though with limited DFU participants. Five studies from the same group reported significantly better healing rates in DFU with NMES combined with heat therapy compared to nondiabetic ulcers.
population_specificity: Individuals with diabetic foot ulceration (DFU).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of Neuromuscular Electrical Stimulation (NMES) on muscle strength, physical variables, and psychosocial outcomes in patients with pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH).
results_summary: The NMES group showed significant improvements in muscle strength, muscle cross-sectional area and thickness, arterial stiffness, exercise capacity, functional mobility and balance, balance confidence, fatigue, physical activity, and quality of life compared to the control group. The study concluded that NMES is safe and effective for PAH patients.
population_specificity: Patients with pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH).
effective_dosage: 50 Hz applied to bilateral deltoid and quadriceps femoris muscles, 3 days/week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Neuromuscular Electrical Stimulation (NMES) is an effective alternative or adjunct to supervised exercise for improving walking distance and quality of life in patients with intermittent claudication.
results_summary: NMES significantly improved maximum and initial claudication distances, quality of life (EQ-5D-5L™), and ICQ scores, both independently and as an adjunct to supervised exercise. Hemodynamic measures also improved significantly during NMES use.
population_specificity: Patients with intermittent claudication.
effective_dosage: Daily use (specific duration per session not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically review the effects of NMES on muscle strength, functional capacity, and quality of life in chronic kidney failure patients on hemodialysis.
results_summary: NMES improved quadriceps muscle strength and functional capacity with moderate-quality evidence, and showed positive effects on upper limb strength and quality of life, though evidence quality was limited for these outcomes.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic kidney failure on hemodialysis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness and safety of exercise-based swallowing therapy (MDTP) combined with NMES versus MDTP alone or usual care for post-stroke dysphagia rehabilitation.
results_summary: MDTP alone showed greater benefits (e.g., reduced dysphagia severity, improved oral intake, earlier return to pre-stroke diet) compared to NMES or usual care. NMES did not outperform MDTP or usual care in improving dysphagia outcomes.
population_specificity: Stroke patients (n=53, mean age 66, 47.2% male) with dysphagia admitted to a sub-acute rehabilitation hospital.
effective_dosage: 1 hour per day of therapy (MDTP + NMES, MDTP + sham NMES, or usual care).
study_duration: 3 weeks of treatment, with follow-up to 3 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the evidence for neuromuscular electrical stimulation as a beneficial exercise training modality for individuals with COPD.
results_summary: The study found that neuromuscular electrical stimulation is among the beneficial exercise training modalities for COPD patients, though specific efficacy details were not provided in the abstract. The review suggests it may facilitate clinical implementation.
population_specificity: Individuals with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of neuromuscular electrical stimulation (NMES) combined with electromyographic biofeedback (EMG-BF) on swallowing function in stroke patients with oropharyngeal dysphagia.
results_summary: The study found statistically significant improvements in swallowing function, as measured by the videofluoroscopic dysphagia scale (VDS) and penetration-aspiration scale (PAS), in both the oral and pharyngeal phases after NMES with EMG-BF intervention.
population_specificity: Stroke patients with oropharyngeal dysphagia (n=10).
effective_dosage: 30 minutes a day, 5 times a week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare swallowing outcomes and discharge destinations in acute stroke patients with tube-feeding dependent dysphagia treated with neuromuscular electrical stimulation (NMES) plus traditional dysphagia therapy versus traditional therapy alone.
results_summary: NMES combined with traditional therapy resulted in significantly higher Functional Oral Intake Scale scores, greater improvements in swallowing function, and more discharges to community settings compared to traditional therapy alone. The NMES group also had fewer transfers back to acute care.
population_specificity: 359 acute stroke patients with profound to severe tube-feeding dependent dysphagia (Functional Oral Intake Scale scores ≤ 3).
effective_dosage: Hourly sessions, 5 days per week (specific NMES parameters not detailed).
study_duration: Duration of inpatient rehabilitation (exact length not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether superimposed NMES combined with strengthening exercises improves quadriceps strength and function in patients with patellofemoral pain (PFP) compared to standardized rehabilitation alone.
results_summary: The study found no clinically significant superiority of superimposed NMES combined with standardized rehabilitation over standardized rehabilitation alone in improving quadriceps strength or functional scores (Kujala and Lysholm) at 6 and 12 weeks. Both groups showed significant within-group improvements, but no between-group differences were observed.
population_specificity: Twenty-seven patients diagnosed with patellofemoral pain (PFP).
effective_dosage: Superimposed NMES administered 3 times per week (specific NMES parameters not detailed).
study_duration: 6 weeks of intervention, with follow-up at 12 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the optimal electrode placement for neuromuscular electrical stimulation (NMES) in treating post-stroke dysphagia.
results_summary: Horizontal electrode placement on the suprahyoid and infrahyoid muscles (Group A) showed significantly greater improvement in dysphagia scores compared to mixed horizontal-vertical (Group B) or vertical placements (Group C). Group A outperformed both other groups in overall Functional Dysphagia Scale (FDS) and pharyngeal-phase FDS scores.
population_specificity: 31 patients with post-stroke dysphagia.
effective_dosage: NMES combined with effortful swallowing training, five times weekly.

study_goal: To compare the effects of two NMES electrode placements (suprahyoid vs. infrahyoid) on swallowing function in stroke patients with dysphagia.
results_summary: Both NMES placements improved swallowing function and oral intake, with no significant difference between groups, though the suprahyoid group showed greater reduction in penetration-aspiration.
population_specificity: Stroke patients with dysphagia (n=26 completed intervention).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether combining neuromuscular electrical stimulation resistance training (RT) with testosterone replacement therapy (TRT) enhances muscle hypertrophy in untrained muscles after spinal cord injury (SCI) compared to TRT alone.
results_summary: The study found that RT combined with TRT significantly increased cross-sectional areas of gluteal muscles (gluteus maximus, medius, and total glutei) compared to TRT alone, suggesting hypertrophy in adjacent untrained muscles. Trunk muscles did not show similar improvements, indicating they may require direct stimulation.
population_specificity: 22 men with chronic motor complete spinal cord injury (SCI).
effective_dosage: TRT (2-6 mg/day via testosterone patches); RT (twice weekly progressive resistance training using electrical stimulation and ankle weights).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether combined electromyography-triggered neuromuscular electrical stimulation and tilt sensor functional electrical stimulation training improves gait performance in stroke patients.
results_summary: Both single and combined electrical stimulation groups showed significant improvement in 10-meter walking tests after two weeks. The combined group also demonstrated better trunk stability (mediolateral plane) compared to the control group.
population_specificity: Thirty-six stroke patients.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of transcutaneous electrical stimulation (TES) as a treatment for lifelong premature ejaculation (PE).
results_summary: TES significantly increased masturbation ejaculatory latency time (MELT) by 3.5-fold compared to sham treatment, with 85% of patients experiencing prolonged MELT. The study suggests TES may be a viable on-demand treatment for PE, though further research is needed to confirm efficacy during intercourse.
population_specificity: 23 male patients aged 20-60 (mean: 38.7) with lifelong PE.
study_duration: At least 7 days between treatment sessions

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of head lift exercise (HLE) and neuromuscular electrical stimulation (NMES) on swallowing muscle activity in healthy elderly individuals.
results_summary: The study found that HLE was more effective than NMES in reducing the duration of suprahyoid muscle activity during swallowing in healthy elderly individuals, suggesting HLE may better counteract aging effects on swallowing physiology.
population_specificity: Healthy elderly adults (23 participants).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to describe how Neuromuscular Electrical Stimulation (NMES) promotes sustained adaptations in central motor pathways to enhance intrinsic functional capacity and inform neurorehabilitation practice.
results_summary: NMES can assist motor rehabilitation by compensating for disability (e.g., hand aperture, foot drop) and may induce central motor pathway adaptations, especially when combined with centrally initiated neural activity (e.g., efferent drive or mental imagery). Adjuvant techniques further enhance adaptive responses, increasing therapeutic potential.
population_specificity: Individuals with motor impairments following brain injury.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether adding neuromuscular electrical stimulation (NMES) to volleyball athletes' training improved muscle strength and jumping skills.
results_summary: The study compared NMES with photobiomodulation therapy and a control group, but the abstract does not specify the exact outcomes for NMES regarding muscle strength and jumping skills.
population_specificity: Thirty-six volleyball athletes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the impact of 12 weeks of NMES-resistance training followed by 12 weeks of FES-lower extremity cycling on oxygen uptake, insulin sensitivity, and glucose effectiveness in persons with spinal cord injury.
results_summary: The study suggests that NMES-RT may evoke muscle hypertrophy and improve oxygen uptake, insulin sensitivity, and glucose effectiveness, potentially benefiting metabolic activity, body composition, and mitochondrial function. Combining NMES-RT with FES-LEC could further reduce muscle wasting and cardio-metabolic risks in SCI patients.
population_specificity: Adults aged 18-65 with chronic spinal cord injury (AIS A-C) at C5-L2 levels.
effective_dosage: Twice-weekly NMES with ankle weights, followed by twice-weekly progressive FES-LEC.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of an EMG-driven NMES cycling system for improving muscle strength and balance in chronic stroke survivors.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in clinical assessment scores (FMA_LE, BBS, 6MWT, and SI) after 20 sessions, indicating that the EMG-driven NMES cycling system effectively enhanced rehabilitation outcomes for stroke survivors.
population_specificity: Chronic stroke survivors (n=10).
effective_dosage: 20 sessions of 30 minutes each, administered 2-4 times per week.
study_duration: Not explicitly stated, but implied over several weeks based on session frequency.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of non-surgical and non-pharmacological interventions, including Neuromuscular Electrical Stimulation, for knee osteoarthritis patients.
results_summary: Neuromuscular Electrical Stimulation showed some positive effects for knee osteoarthritis patients, but more studies are needed to fully recommend its use. The results were not as strong as those for exercise, pulsed electromagnetic fields, or moxibustion.
population_specificity: Humans with knee osteoarthritis

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether combining short foot exercise (SFE) with neuromuscular electrical stimulation (NMES) improves navicular height, abductor hallucis (AbdH) muscle cross-sectional area, and AbdH muscle activity in individuals with flexible flatfoot compared to SFE alone.
results_summary: The study found that SFE with NMES significantly increased AbdH muscle activity compared to SFE alone (81.4% vs. 73.9% of MVIC). Additionally, the AbdH muscle cross-sectional area significantly increased post-treatment in the NMES group, though no significant differences were observed in navicular height between groups.
population_specificity: Thirty-six otherwise healthy individuals with flexible flatfoot.
effective_dosage: Not specified (NMES parameters not detailed in the abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review neuromuscular development, summarize evidence on NMES use in infants, and identify potential contraindications for neonates and young infants.
results_summary: Current evidence supporting NMES in pediatric populations is limited and of poor quality, with identified contraindications including inhibited neural cell adhesion molecule expression, altered muscle fiber metabolic profiles, and disrupted acetylcholine receptor synthesis. The study concludes that NMES may influence early neuromuscular development in ways not yet well understood.
population_specificity: Neonates and young infants

study_goal: To compare the effects of an integrated program of physical and electrical therapy versus standard rehabilitation on physical and functional performance in elderly patients with pneumonia.
results_summary: The integrated program significantly improved physical and functional performance in elderly pneumonia patients compared to standard rehabilitation, with notable differences in outcomes such as handgrip strength and independence levels. Secondary respiratory symptoms like dyspnoea, fatigue, and cough also showed improvement.
population_specificity: Elderly patients (mean age ~74 years) hospitalized with pneumonia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify best practice strategies, including Neuromuscular Electrical Stimulation, for addressing glenohumeral subluxation.
results_summary: The review found that Neuromuscular Electrical Stimulation was supported by the highest number of high-quality studies (n = 19, including five level I studies), indicating its effectiveness. No evidence suggested harm from using this intervention.
population_specificity: Adults with glenohumeral subluxation (pediatric population not reviewed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the dose-response relationship between NMES and muscle function in individuals with rheumatoid arthritis and establish the minimal NMES training intensity for promoting improvements.
results_summary: The study found that NMES improved quadriceps cross-sectional area, muscle quality, and strength in individuals with RA, with significant associations between NMES training intensity and muscle quality/strength. The minimum effective NMES training intensity ranged from 11% to 20% of maximum voluntary isometric contraction.
population_specificity: Adults diagnosed with rheumatoid arthritis (75% women; mean age 58 years; mean BMI 32 kg/m²).
effective_dosage: 36 NMES treatment sessions over 16 weeks, with intensity calculated as a percentage of maximum voluntary isometric contraction (11%-20% found effective).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether neuromuscular electrical stimulation (NES) combined with usual care improves global muscle strength and clinical outcomes (ICU mortality, duration of mechanical ventilation, ICU length of stay) compared to usual care alone in critically ill patients.
results_summary: NES combined with usual care showed no significant differences in global muscle strength, ICU mortality, duration of mechanical ventilation, or ICU length of stay compared to usual care alone. The study concluded that further RCTs are needed to identify patients who may benefit most and to examine NES safety and efficacy.
population_specificity: Adult ICU patients (mean age 60 ± 15.3 years, 60.6% male) with medical or surgical diseases, both mechanically ventilated and non-ventilated.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the rehabilitation effectiveness of NMES-robotic systems when supporting distal finger joints versus proximal wrist-elbow joints in chronic stroke patients.
results_summary: Both groups showed significant improvements in UE motor function, but the hand group (distal support) demonstrated faster reductions in muscle activation levels and co-contraction indices, as well as better improvements in finger motor function and muscle spasticity release.
population_specificity: Thirty subjects with chronic stroke.
study_duration: Training duration not explicitly stated, but follow-up assessments were conducted 3 months post-training.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of Russian current (RC) and pulsed current (PC) neuromuscular electrical stimulation on neuromuscular adaptations after a 6-week training program in soccer players.
results_summary: Both RC and PC increased evoked torque and improved muscle architecture (thickness and pennation angle), with PC showing less perceived discomfort. No significant differences were found between RC and PC for maximal voluntary isometric contraction or electromyographic activity.
population_specificity: 27 male soccer players (average age ~22 years).
effective_dosage: 3 sessions per week for 6 weeks (RC: 2500 Hz, burst 100 Hz, phase duration 200 μs; PC: 100 Hz, 200 μs).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the therapeutic effects of neuromuscular electrical stimulation (NMES) on improving masticatory muscle function and sleep-related physiological variables in individuals with Down syndrome.
results_summary: The study proposed evaluating NMES alongside other interventions (mastication apparatus and mandibular advancement oral appliance) but did not report specific results for NMES in the abstract. The primary outcomes targeted were functional improvement of masticatory muscles and sleep variables.
population_specificity: Individuals with Down syndrome presenting masticatory muscle hypotonia and obstructive sleep apnea.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether adding transcutaneous nerve stimulation or neuromuscular electrical stimulation to standard early rehabilitation improves postural stability and mobility in acute stroke patients.
results_summary: Transcutaneous nerve stimulation combined with standard early rehabilitation significantly improved Postural Assessment Scale for Stroke Patients scores and walking ability compared to standard rehabilitation alone. No significant differences were reported for neuromuscular electrical stimulation in the abstract.
population_specificity: First-stroke patients aged 20-80 years admitted within 24 hours post-stroke.
effective_dosage: 30 minutes per day, five days per week, applied to the affected tibialis anterior and quadriceps muscles.

study_goal: To evaluate whether NMES, as an adjunct to standard care, improves absolute walking distance in patients with intermittent claudication compared to standard care alone.
results_summary: The study aimed to measure changes in walking distance at 3 months, along with secondary outcomes like quality of life and hemodynamic measures, but results are not yet provided in the abstract.
population_specificity: Patients with intermittent claudication in England.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of laryngopharyngeal neuromuscular electrical stimulation (NMES) on dysphagia caused by subacute stroke.
results_summary: The study found that NMES combined with traditional dysphagia training significantly improved primary outcomes (swallowing function, aspiration, and secretion) compared to traditional training alone, with secondary outcomes also showing significant improvement.
population_specificity: Subacute stroke patients with dysphagia (n=33).

study_goal: To determine if NMES as an adjuvant therapy improves gross motor function in children with spastic cerebral palsy.
results_summary: NMES combined with other therapies showed a medium effect size in improving gross motor function, particularly in sitting and standing dimensions, but not in walking. The evidence quality was rated as low.
population_specificity: Children with spastic cerebral palsy (pooled n=174).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate neuromuscular adaptations induced by 3 weeks of wide-pulse high-frequency (WPHF) neuromuscular electrical stimulation (NMES) compared to conventional NMES.
results_summary: The study found that WPHF NMES increased electrically evoked forces (total FTI +118% and mean evoked forces +96%) but did not induce changes in other plantar flexor neuromuscular function parameters. No improvements were observed in the control group.
population_specificity: Ten young healthy individuals (training group) and seven individuals (control group).
effective_dosage: Ten 20-second WPHF NMES contractions at 100 Hz, interspaced by 40-second recovery, delivered at an intensity evoking ~5% of MVC force, repeated over nine sessions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically review the evidence for interventions, including Neuromuscular Electrical Stimulation (NMES), for managing and preventing sarcopenia in critically ill patients.
results_summary: NMES was most frequently studied as an intervention to preserve muscle mass in critically ill patients, but there was significant variation in its efficacy on sarcopenia markers and secondary outcomes. The study concluded that NMES may preserve muscle mass, though effects were inconsistent.
population_specificity: Critically ill patients at risk of or experiencing sarcopenia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of EMG-NMES on upper limb recovery in stroke patients across different ICF domains (Body Structure and Function, Activity and Participation).
results_summary: EMG-NMES showed a robust short-term effect on improving upper limb motor impairment in the Body Structure and Function domain but no significant effect on the Activity and Participation domain. The treatment was more effective in chronic stroke patients compared to acute/subacute phases.
population_specificity: Patients with stroke (acute/subacute and chronic phases).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the feasibility and effectiveness of self-managed strengthening strategies, including NMES, for improving knee strength, function, pain, and activity in military members with knee injuries compared to usual PT.
results_summary: The COMBO group (NMES + strength walking) showed statistically significant improvements in knee extension and flexion strength compared to PT-only, but NMES alone did not. Pain, function, and ADLS improved across all groups with no significant differences.
population_specificity: Active duty military members with knee injuries.
effective_dosage: Not specified (only adherence rates: NMES group completed 34% of recommended sessions, COMBO group 30%).

study_goal: To compare the effectiveness of contralaterally controlled functional electrical stimulation (CCFES) versus conventional neuromuscular electrical stimulation (NMES) in recovering wrist dorsiflexion and upper limb function in early-phase stroke patients.
results_summary: CCFES significantly improved the rate and speed of wrist dorsiflexion recovery compared to NMES, with higher functional scores in upper extremity function, strength, range of motion, daily living activities, and general health.
population_specificity: Patients with early-phase stroke (<15 days post-stroke).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether starting swallowing therapy (including neuromuscular electrical stimulation) sooner after radiotherapy improved outcomes compared to later initiation.
results_summary: The study found that starting therapy within 1 year post-radiotherapy led to better quality of life and diet performance compared to later initiation, but no significant difference in swallowing physiological variables was observed between groups.
population_specificity: Head and neck cancer patients with swallowing dysfunction after radiotherapy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of neuromuscular electrical stimulation (NMES) therapy for chronic urinary retention (CUR) following traumatic brain injury (TBI).
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in post-voiding residual urine volume, voided volume, maximum urinary flow rate, or quality of life between the NMES and sham groups after 8 weeks of treatment and 4 weeks of follow-up. No adverse events were reported in either group.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic urinary retention following traumatic brain injury (n=86).
effective_dosage: Not specified (NMES or sham NMES administered for 8 weeks).

study_goal: To evaluate the efficacy of neuromuscular electrical stimulation on quadriceps muscle strength and thickness in liver transplantation patients.
results_summary: Neuromuscular electrical stimulation maintained quadriceps muscle thickness post-surgery but did not significantly improve quadriceps strength or walking distance compared to the control group.
population_specificity: Patients following living donor liver transplantation.
effective_dosage: 30 minutes per session, once per day for five weekdays over four weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the optimal NMES frequency for postprandial glycemic control and compare discomfort and muscle soreness between different frequencies in healthy individuals.
results_summary: Five-hertz NMES significantly reduced glycemia, while 10 Hz and 50 Hz did not. Ten-hertz NMES caused less discomfort, and 50 Hz caused greater muscle soreness; women reported higher discomfort than men.
population_specificity: Sixteen healthy, sedentary participants.
effective_dosage: NMES at 5, 10, or 50 Hz (pulse duration: 400 μs, on-off ratio: 4:12 s) for 20 minutes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of neuromuscular electrical stimulation (NMES) therapy in patients with urinary incontinence after stroke (UIAS).
