results_summary: NMES therapy significantly improved primary endpoints (urodynamic values and OABSS) and secondary endpoints (ICIQ-SF and BI scores) compared to sham treatment, with no adverse events reported.
population_specificity: 82 patients with urinary incontinence after stroke (UIAS).
effective_dosage: Not specified (NMES therapy administered for 10 weeks).

study_goal: To determine the effects of neuromuscular electrical stimulation (NMES) on muscle architecture and functional capacity in patients with knee osteoarthritis compared to ultrasound therapy.
results_summary: The NMES group showed significant improvements in muscle thickness and fascicle length compared to the ultrasound therapy group, though ultrasound therapy was more effective in reducing pain and improving functional capacity. Both groups demonstrated significant improvements in all outcome measures post-treatment.
population_specificity: 60 patients with knee osteoarthritis.
effective_dosage: Five days a week for three weeks (specific NMES parameters not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the technical aspects, therapeutic and functional benefits, and barriers of Neuromuscular Electrical Stimulation (NMES), including its historical development and modern applications.
results_summary: The study highlights that NMES, particularly in therapeutic (TES) and functional (FES) applications, has evolved significantly, with modern devices being more convenient and reliable. FES has shown significant benefits in enhancing upper limb function, though early commercial devices faced challenges in widespread adoption.
population_specificity: Not specified (general review, no specific population studied).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effectiveness and safety of neuromuscular electrical stimulation (NMES) for treating chronic low back pain (CLBP) compared to usual care.
results_summary: The study found no significant improvement in pain intensity or disability in the NMES group compared to the control group after 4 weeks of treatment. No adverse events related to NMES were reported.
population_specificity: 72 patients with chronic low back pain (CLBP).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the clinical impact of neuromuscular electrical stimulation as a treatment for patients with oedema.
results_summary: Six out of seven studies supported the use of neuromuscular electrical stimulation for oedema reduction, while one study found no effect but reported inter-group variance. The review concluded that neuromuscular electrical stimulation is effective in various rehabilitation settings for treating upper and lower limb oedema.
population_specificity: Patients with oedema (both upper and lower limb).

study_goal: To investigate whether supplementing stabilization exercises with neuromuscular electrical stimulation provides additional clinical benefits for patients with chronic low back pain.
results_summary: Neuromuscular electrical stimulation was tolerable but did not show significant additional benefits compared to stabilization exercises alone. No significant differences were found in pain, disability, fear-avoidance beliefs, or muscle strength between the two groups.
population_specificity: Adults aged 18-60 with chronic low back pain (≥3 months), BMI ≤34, and moderate pain/disability scores.
effective_dosage: 20 minutes per session, twice a week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether perioperative neuromuscular electrical stimulation reduces muscle proteolysis and improves physical function in patients undergoing cardiovascular surgery.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in muscle proteolysis or physical function outcomes (knee extensor strength, walking speed, grip strength) between the intervention and control groups, suggesting neuromuscular electrical stimulation had no measurable benefit in this context.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing cardiovascular surgery (n=119, intervention=60, control=59).
effective_dosage: Bilateral leg stimulation 8 times before and after surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize current knowledge about CKD-induced muscle atrophy and evaluate the effectiveness of multidisciplinary treatments, including neuromuscular electrical stimulation.
results_summary: The abstract mentions neuromuscular electrical stimulation as part of a multidisciplinary approach to treating CKD-induced muscle atrophy, but specific results or outcomes for this intervention are not detailed.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic kidney disease (CKD)-induced muscle atrophy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of NMES on walking ability, muscle strength, functional independence, and quality of life in cardiac valve surgery patients during the immediate postoperative period.
results_summary: The study found no significant effect of NMES on walking ability, muscle strength, functional independence, or quality of life in postoperative cardiac valve surgery patients. Upper-limb muscle strength loss and mobility decline at postoperative day 3 recovered similarly in both groups by day 5.
population_specificity: Adult patients undergoing cardiac valve reconstruction and/or replacement.
effective_dosage: 60 minutes per session, bilaterally applied to quadriceps and gastrocnemius, for up to 10 sessions.
study_duration: Up to 10 sessions (exact total duration not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of whole-body neuromuscular electrical stimulation (WBS) on body composition, functional capacity, muscle strength, insulin resistance, and inflammatory markers in obese patients undergoing bariatric surgery.
results_summary: The study suggests WBS is a safe and effective tool for improving muscle mass, glucose uptake, and reducing inflammation, potentially aiding early rehabilitation in bariatric surgery patients. However, final data were not yet published at the time of the abstract.
population_specificity: Obese patients (BMI > 35 kg/m²) undergoing bariatric surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of swallowing therapy, including Neuromuscular Electrical Stimulation (NMES), on death or dependency among stroke survivors with dysphagia within six months of stroke onset.
results_summary: The study found no significant effect of swallowing therapy, including NMES, on the primary outcome of death or dependency/disability. However, NMES may have contributed to reducing dysphagia and improving swallowing ability, though evidence quality was variable.
population_specificity: Stroke survivors with dysphagia within six months of stroke onset.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effectiveness of noninvasive neurostimulation therapies, including surface neuromuscular electrical stimulation (sNMES), in improving swallowing function in patients with poststroke dysphagia.
results_summary: The study found that sNMES significantly improved poststroke dysphagia compared to placebo, though rTMS was ranked as the most effective therapy among the four neurostimulation methods evaluated. Differences in functional improvement between PES and placebo were not significant.
population_specificity: Patients with acute and subacute poststroke dysphagia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of NMES, NTS, and a hybrid of both on upper extremity motor recovery in chronic stroke patients.
results_summary: The hybrid therapy showed significant improvements in UE-FMA scores from baseline to posttreatment and follow-up, but no significant differences were found between NMES, NTS, and hybrid groups in overall outcomes.
population_specificity: Chronic stroke patients (onset >6 months) with mild-to-moderate disability in daily living.
effective_dosage: 30 min of NMES or NTS, or 15 min of NTS followed by 15 min of NMES, 3 days/week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether neuromuscular electrical stimulation (NMES) combined with physical training improves wrist dysfunction recovery in patients after acute ischemic stroke (AIS) compared to physical training alone.
results_summary: The study found no significant improvement in arm function recovery (ARAT score), activities of daily living (BI scale), or pain reduction (NRS scale) in the NMES group compared to the control group after 4 weeks of treatment.
population_specificity: 82 patients with wrist dysfunction following acute ischemic stroke (AIS).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify the range of stimulation parameters for neuromuscular electrical stimulation (NMES) and functional electrical stimulation (FES) that may alleviate spasticity after spinal cord injury.
results_summary: NMES/FES reduced spasticity by 45%-60%, decreased electromyography activity, and increased range of motion. The effective stimulation parameters were frequency of 20-30 Hz, pulse duration of 300-350 μs, and current amplitude greater than 100 mA.
population_specificity: Individuals with spasticity after spinal cord injury (389 subjects across 23 trials).
effective_dosage: Frequency: 20-30 Hz; Pulse duration: 300-350 μs; Current amplitude: >100 mA.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the convergent validity and responsiveness of the Stroke Upper Limb Capacity Scale (SULCS) compared to other measures in patients receiving neuromuscular electrical stimulation therapy.
results_summary: The SULCS showed strong correlation with other upper limb capacity measures (AMAT, BBT, FMA) and demonstrated moderate to large responsiveness, with no significant difference in effectiveness compared to the other measures. Neuromuscular electrical stimulation therapy contributed to improved upper limb capacity in poststroke patients.
population_specificity: Patients less than 2 years poststroke with moderate to severe upper limb hemiparesis (N=61).
study_duration: 12 weeks of therapy, with follow-up assessments up to 36 weeks.

study_goal: To determine if adding neuromuscular electrical stimulation to pulmonary rehabilitation improves walking tolerance and balance in COPD patients compared to pulmonary rehabilitation alone.
results_summary: The intervention group showed significant improvements in walking distance, balance (measured by time up and go, Berg balance scale), and maximal voluntary contraction compared to the control group. Center of pressure measures also improved more in the intervention group.
population_specificity: 45 patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Neuromuscular Electrical Stimulation (NMES) could serve as a bridge or alternative to conventional exercise for patients with advanced chronic heart failure (CHF) who are non-compliant or non-responsive to physical training.
results_summary: The study found that NMES improves functional capacity, muscle mass, endurance, vascular endothelial function, quality of life, and aerobic enzyme activity in CHF patients. Additionally, NMES can be administered as a home-based therapy after patient guidance.
population_specificity: Patients with advanced chronic heart failure (CHF) who are non-compliant or non-responsive to physical training.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of NMES on health and QoL in adult cancer survivors, assess its safety, and identify common treatment parameters.
results_summary: NMES showed a non-significant improvement in muscle strength but significantly improved HR-QoL, particularly in QoL Function. Current NMES prescription lacks standardization and is tailored to individual functional deficits.
population_specificity: Adult cancer survivors

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether NMES as an adjunctive therapy to DHC improves outcomes in patients with diarrhea-predominant irritable bowel syndrome (BP-IBS).
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in effectiveness (VAS, stool frequency, Bristol scale) or adverse events between the NMES+DHC group and the DHC-only group, suggesting NMES may not be efficacious for BP-IBS after 4 weeks.
population_specificity: 108 patients with diarrhea-predominant irritable bowel syndrome (BP-IBS).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Neuromuscular Electrical Stimulation (NMES) is effective in reducing pain and improving functional status and quality of life in patients with postpartum low back pain (PPLBP).
results_summary: The study found that NMES did not significantly improve pain relief, functional status, or quality of life in patients with PPLBP after a 4-week treatment period. No adverse events related to the treatment were reported.
population_specificity: 67 patients with postpartum low back pain (PPLBP).
effective_dosage: Each session lasted 30 minutes, administered once weekly.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Neuromuscular Electrical Stimulation (NMES) could effectively manage fatigue, anxiety, depression, and sleep quality in patients with advanced laryngeal cancer undergoing chemoradiotherapy.
results_summary: The study found that NMES did not provide significant benefits over the control group in reducing fatigue, anxiety, depression, or improving sleep quality after 8 weeks of treatment.
population_specificity: 60 patients with advanced laryngeal cancer receiving chemoradiotherapy.

study_goal: To review the evidence on the safety of neuromuscular electrical stimulation (NMES) when used in the intensive care unit.
results_summary: NMES was found to be safe for critically ill patients, with minor adverse effects such as a prickling sensation (15% of patients) and one case of a superficial burn due to improper parameter configuration. Hemodynamic changes were noted in one study but were not clinically relevant.
population_specificity: Critically ill patients in the intensive care unit.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness and safety of Neuromuscular Electrical Stimulation (NMES) for treating endometriosis-associated pain (EAP).
results_summary: After 10 weeks of NMES therapy, significant improvements were observed in pain reduction (NRS, ESSS) and quality of life (SF-36) compared to the control group, with no significant differences in adverse events between groups.
population_specificity: 154 patients with endometriosis-associated pain.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of neuromuscular electrical stimulation (NMES) on post-stroke urinary incontinence (PSUI) in female patients, comparing outcomes with a control group receiving only bladder training.
results_summary: After 8 weeks, NMES significantly reduced urine leakage, improved urinary symptoms (measured by BFUSQ), and enhanced quality of life (measured by ICIQ-SF) compared to the control group, with no adverse events reported. No significant benefits were observed after 4 weeks.
population_specificity: Female patients in China with post-stroke urinary incontinence (n=163).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of mental practice (MP) combined with neurofeedback, specifically MP-guided neuromuscular electrical stimulation (NMES), for upper limb rehabilitation after stroke.
results_summary: MP-guided NMES showed superior results compared to conventional NMES, as measured by Fugl-Meyer Assessment (FMA) gain. However, the study noted limitations due to heterogeneity and inadequate quality of trials.
population_specificity: Stroke patients undergoing upper limb rehabilitation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness and safety of percutaneous neuromuscular electrical stimulation (PNMES) for treating neck pain in patients with cervical spondylosis (CS).
results_summary: PNMES significantly reduced neck pain (measured by VAS and NDI) and improved cervical range of motion compared to sham treatment, with no adverse events reported in either group.
population_specificity: 124 patients with neck pain due to cervical spondylosis.
study_duration: 12 weeks of treatment, with a 4-week follow-up.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the potential of neuromuscular electrical stimulation (NMES) as an alternative therapy for improving muscle strength, muscle mass, and cardiorespiratory function in older adults, while addressing barriers to its clinical acceptability.
results_summary: The study highlights that NMES has positive effects on muscle strength, muscle mass, and cardiorespiratory function in older adults, but faces challenges in clinical acceptability and patient adherence. It suggests that integrating technology-based supports like biofeedback and gamification could enhance NMES effectiveness and adoption.
population_specificity: Older adults with low exercise participation and activity levels, experiencing sarcopenia and decreased cardiovascular function.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the efficacy of a hybrid training system (HTS) combining neuromuscular electrical stimulation and volitional contractions for improving thigh muscle strength, knee pain relief, and physical performance in women with or at risk for knee osteoarthritis.
results_summary: The HTS improved quadriceps and hamstring strength, reduced knee pain, and enhanced physical performance, but these benefits were not statistically superior to low-load resistance training alone. Both interventions showed similar effectiveness in pain relief and functional improvement.
population_specificity: Women aged 44-85 years with risk factors for knee osteoarthritis.
effective_dosage: Biweekly low-load resistance training sessions over 12 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effect of prolonged NMES on metabolic profile and cognition-related blood parameters in patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM).
results_summary: NMES training significantly improved fasting glucose concentration and reduced percent body fat but did not significantly affect HbA1c or blood lipid levels. Plasma BDNF levels increased significantly during the NMES period compared to the control.
population_specificity: Fourteen patients with T2DM (mean age 63.2 years, mean weight 76.1 kg).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the feasibility and effectiveness of NMES versus high-intensity volitional resistance training for improving muscle structure, function, and physical function in rheumatoid arthritis patients.
results_summary: Both NMES and volitional training significantly improved muscle structure and function, with no difference in outcomes between groups. NMES had higher attrition (29%) but no serious adverse events or increases in pain/disease activity.
population_specificity: Adult patients with rheumatoid arthritis (RA).
effective_dosage: 36 sessions over 16 weeks (intensity: 31% of maximum effort for NMES vs. 77% for volitional training).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether neuromuscular electrical stimulation (NMES) applied to the triceps surae muscles could improve mobility and muscle function in older adults.
results_summary: NMES improved 400-meter walk time and maximal walking speed by Week 4, with further improvements in chair-rise and rapid-step tests by Week 7, though plantar flexor strength only increased at Week 7. No significant differences were found between narrow- and wide-pulse NMES groups.
population_specificity: Thirty healthy older adults (73.5 ± 4.8 years).
effective_dosage: 3 weekly sessions of either narrow- or wide-pulse NMES.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of NMES and TENS in reducing hemiplegic shoulder pain (HSP) and improving related functional outcomes in stroke patients.
results_summary: NMES showed significantly greater pain reduction (NRS) compared to TENS and control groups after 4 weeks, with long-term analgesic superiority. However, NMES did not outperform TENS or control in improving shoulder mobility, limb function, spasticity, daily activity, or quality of life.
population_specificity: 90 participants with hemiplegic shoulder pain in a rehabilitation hospital setting.
effective_dosage: NMES (15Hz, 200μs pulse width) applied for 1 hour daily, 20 sessions over 4 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of combining neuromuscular electrical stimulation with effortful swallowing on dysphagia in Parkinson's disease patients.
results_summary: The experimental group showed significant improvements in hyoid bone movement and reduced aspiration but no significant differences in oral or pharyngeal phases of swallowing.
population_specificity: Dysphagic patients with Parkinson's disease (n=18, split into experimental and placebo groups).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the fatigue origins induced by low-frequency pulsed current (PC) and medium-frequency current (MF) neuromuscular electrical stimulation (NMES) after a clinical-like session.
results_summary: Both PC and MF NMES induced similar decreases in maximal voluntary contraction, electromyographic activity, and evoked contractile properties, with no significant differences between the two currents. The study concluded that clinicians can expect similar treatment effects from either PC or MF when the goal is muscle strength gains.
population_specificity: Eleven healthy men.
effective_dosage: 15-minute duration, 6 seconds on and 18 seconds off.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and impact of NMES combined with traditional therapy on swallowing function in patients with dysphagia of neurological origin.
results_summary: NMES combined with traditional therapy significantly improved swallowing function in 9 out of 10 patients, with minimal adverse effects (1.3% incidence of minor adverse events). Additionally, 30% of subjects showed improved voice quality.
population_specificity: Adults with dysphagia of neurological origin who had not achieved adequate swallowing function with traditional therapy alone.
effective_dosage: NMES + traditional therapy delivered three times a week for 5 weeks.
study_duration: 10 weeks total (5 weeks traditional therapy followed by 5 weeks NMES + traditional therapy).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether unilateral quadriceps NMES and focal vibration could enhance contralateral muscle strength and neural drive in healthy subjects.
results_summary: The study found that both NMES and focal vibration increased MVC torque and voluntary activation in the contralateral quadriceps, with NMES showing greater increases in neural drive and EMG activity compared to vibration. Inter-individual variability was noted, with "responders" showing significant improvements.
population_specificity: Healthy subjects

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether simultaneous neuromuscular electrical stimulation (NMES) enhances the effects of a functional training program in hospitalized geriatric patients.
results_summary: Both functional training with and without NMES improved physical function, but NMES provided no additional benefit. NMES sessions were more time-consuming and caused higher discomfort compared to functional training alone.
population_specificity: Hospitalized geriatric patients (mean age 83.1 ± 8.1 years).
effective_dosage: Not specified (NMES applied to knee extensor muscles during functional training).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether neuromuscular electrical stimulation (NMES) could reduce genomic damage in chronic kidney failure (CKF) patients undergoing conventional haemodialysis.
results_summary: NMES significantly reduced DNA damage in CKF patients after both 4 and 8 weeks of intervention compared to baseline and the control group, demonstrating its potential to mitigate genomic damage.
population_specificity: Chronic kidney failure patients on conventional haemodialysis (n=21).
effective_dosage: Applied on the quadriceps muscle during haemodialysis sessions, three times a week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of postdischarge interventions, including neuromuscular electrical stimulation, in reducing chronic pain severity after total knee replacement.
results_summary: The study found no evidence that neuromuscular electrical stimulation was more effective than other interventions at reducing chronic pain severity after total knee replacement. Only one trial evaluated this intervention, and it did not show a significant difference in long-term pain outcomes.
population_specificity: Patients who underwent total knee replacement surgery.

study_goal: To determine if neuromuscular electrical stimulation improves negative affect disorders (anxiety, depression) and swallowing function in cerebral infarction patients with dysphagia.
results_summary: Neuromuscular electrical stimulation combined with conventional therapy significantly improved swallowing function (88.1% vs. 69.8%) and reduced anxiety and depression scores compared to conventional therapy alone.
population_specificity: 112 patients with cerebral infarction and dysphagia.
study_duration: Two courses of treatment (duration per course not specified)

study_goal: To determine if home-based neuromuscular electrical stimulation (NMES) as an add-on to pulmonary rehabilitation (PR) improves functional capacity in severe to very severe COPD patients.
results_summary: NMES did not provide additional benefits over PR alone in improving functional capacity or other outcomes in COPD patients. The intervention was well-tolerated, with only one dropout due to leg discomfort.
population_specificity: Subjects with severe to very severe COPD (median FEV1 of 1L).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of NMES, TENS, and EA in improving rehabilitation outcomes following total knee arthroplasty (TKA).
results_summary: NMES was associated with higher quadriceps strength and functional recovery post-TKA, with optimal benefits achieved at specific stimulation parameters. NMES and TENS were found to effectively improve rehabilitation without significant intolerance, while EA may aid in analgesia.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing total knee arthroplasty (TKA).
effective_dosage: Intensity of 100-120 mA, frequency of 30-100 Hz, once or twice daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify and characterize the most frequently cited articles on pelvic floor physiotherapy, including neuromuscular electrical stimulation, to assess their scientific impact and prevalence.
results_summary: Neuromuscular electrical stimulation was identified as one of the common topics among highly cited classic articles in pelvic floor physiotherapy, indicating its recognized role in the field. The study noted a high scientific level among these papers, particularly due to the prevalence of randomized clinical trials.
population_specificity: Patients with pelvic floor dysfunctions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of Neuromuscular Electrical Stimulation (NMES) on endothelial progenitor cell mobilization and metabolic/hemodynamic outcomes in patients with septic shock.
results_summary: The study protocol proposes evaluating NMES in septic shock patients, with primary focus on endothelial progenitor cell mobilization and secondary outcomes including metabolic and hemodynamic data, but results are not yet reported as this is a study protocol.
population_specificity: 31 patients aged 18-65 years with septic shock in an intensive care unit.
study_duration: Phase one within first 72 hours of septic shock, phase two after 3 days of first assessment, with a wash-out period of 4-6 hours between protocols.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of narrow- and wide-pulse NMES on walking performance, neuromuscular function, and disability status in persons with relapsing-remitting MS.
results_summary: The NMES intervention improved gait speed, walking endurance, muscle strength in specific leg muscles, force control, and self-reported fatigue and walking limitations, with no significant difference between narrow- and wide-pulse durations.
population_specificity: Individuals with relapsing-remitting MS (mean age 52.6 ± 7.4 years).
effective_dosage: 10 minutes per muscle (dorsiflexor and plantar flexor muscles of both legs), 4 s on and 12 s off, at a tolerable level for 18 sessions across 6 weeks.

study_goal: To investigate the effectiveness of neuromuscular electrical stimulation (NMES) with or without other interventions in improving lower limb activity after chronic stroke.
results_summary: NMES showed a moderate but statistically significant benefit on lower limb motor function, especially when combined with other interventions or administered within 6 or 12 weeks. It also improved gait speed, balance, spasticity, and range of motion but had no significant effect on walking endurance.
population_specificity: Chronic stroke survivors with lower limb dysfunction.
study_duration: Treatment time within either 6 or 12 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of the Ampcare Effective Swallowing Protocol (combining NMES with swallow-strengthening exercises) with usual care for treating post-stroke dysphagia and to pilot recruitment procedures for a larger trial.
results_summary: The Ampcare ESP group showed greater improvement (75% vs. 57%) and clinically meaningful benefits in swallowing function (FOIS and PAS scores) compared to usual care, with higher patient satisfaction. The pilot demonstrated feasibility and promising efficacy for NMES in dysphagia rehabilitation.
population_specificity: Post-stroke patients with dysphagia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the skeletal muscle anabolic signaling response to low-frequency (20 Hz) and high-frequency (60 Hz) neuromuscular electrical stimulation (NMES) in healthy volunteers.
results_summary: HF-NMES (60 Hz) produced a greater anabolic response than LF-NMES (20 Hz), significantly upregulating phosphorylation of key signaling proteins like mTOR and p70-S6 kinase 1, suggesting HF stimulation may better initiate muscle hypertrophy. LF-NMES also showed anabolic effects but to a lesser extent.
population_specificity: Eleven young healthy volunteers (6 men, 5 women).
effective_dosage: Acute bouts of LF-NMES (20 Hz) and HF-NMES (60 Hz).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if sNMES combined with traditional dysphagia therapy improves swallowing function in post-stroke dysphagia patients and whether electrode placement affects outcomes.
results_summary: Swallowing function significantly improved in patients receiving sNMES combined with traditional therapy, with no significant difference between electrode placements. Suprahyoid stimulation further enhanced anterior hyoid bone movement.
population_specificity: Thirty patients with post-stroke dysphagia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of three different waveforms (2500-Hz BMAC, 1000-Hz BMAC, and 1000-Hz BMBPC) in eliciting knee extensor torque using neuromuscular electrical stimulation (NMES).
results_summary: The study found that 1000-Hz BMBPC and 1000-Hz BMAC were similarly effective in producing knee extensor torque, while 2500-Hz BMAC was less effective. Statistically significant differences were observed between 2500-Hz BMAC and the other two waveforms.
population_specificity: 33 able-bodied participants (18 female).
effective_dosage: Maximum tolerated stimulation intensity (no specific dosage provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of low-frequency pulsed current versus kilohertz-frequency alternating current in terms of evoked force, discomfort, current intensity, and muscle fatigability, and to determine which is better for clinical treatment.
results_summary: Kilohertz-frequency alternating current generated equal or less force, similar discomfort, similar current intensity for maximal tolerated stimulation, and more fatigue compared with low-frequency pulsed current. At submaximal force levels, kilohertz-frequency current caused higher discomfort and required higher current intensity than low-frequency pulsed current.
population_specificity: Not specified (studies comparing the two current types were reviewed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of combining Neuromuscular Electrical Stimulation (NMES) with conventional treatment versus conventional treatment alone in preventing shoulder pain after stroke.
results_summary: The study found that combining NMES with conventional treatment was no more effective than conventional treatment alone in preventing hemiplegic shoulder pain, with no significant differences in disability, function, or pain outcomes between groups. Shoulder pain increased after the first month in all groups.
population_specificity: First-time stroke survivors (58.06% female).
study_duration: Measurements taken at baseline and weeks 1, 2, 3, 4, 12, and 24 post-stroke.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to reexamine fundamental aspects of Neuromuscular Electrical Stimulation (NMES) from a tripartite model perspective to improve its clinical effectiveness.
results_summary: The study found that NMES involves neurally mediated responses contributing to force generation and neural adaptations, emphasized the importance of muscle tension over external stimulation parameters, and advocated for a systematic, patient-specific approach to NMES therapy.
population_specificity: Not specified (general neuromuscular rehabilitation context).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects (benefits and harms) of neuromuscular electrical stimulation (NMES) for people with patellofemoral pain (PFP).
results_summary: The review found very low-quality evidence suggesting NMES may reduce pain short-term when combined with exercise, but the clinical relevance is uncertain. No significant improvements in knee function were observed, and adverse effects were not reported.
population_specificity: Participants with patellofemoral pain (PFP), mean ages 25-43 years, predominantly female (53%-100%).
effective_dosage: Varied across studies, including one with NMES applied four hours daily for four weeks.
study_duration: Ranged from 3 to 12 weeks in most studies, with one follow-up at one year.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if neuromuscular electrical stimulation (NMES) of calf muscles could prevent spontaneous calf cramps in individuals experiencing frequent cramps.
results_summary: NMES reduced spontaneous calf cramps by 78% in stimulated legs and 63% in unstimulated legs, with an increased cramp threshold frequency only in the stimulated leg. The severity of remaining cramps also tended to decrease in both legs.
population_specificity: 19 individuals affected by ≥1 calf cramp per week.
effective_dosage: Twice weekly stimulation (3 × 6 stimulation trains at 30 Hz above individual cramp threshold frequency).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effectiveness of neuromuscular electrical stimulation (NMES) in preventing venous thromboembolism (VTE) compared to no prophylaxis or alternative methods.
results_summary: NMES showed lower risks of total DVT and total VTE compared to no prophylaxis but was associated with higher risk of total DVT compared to low-dose heparin. No clear differences were found between NMES and alternative prophylaxis methods for other outcomes.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing major surgery, hip fracture surgery, trauma with heparin contraindication, neurosurgery under general anesthesia, and non-functional spinal cord injuries.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the immediate and retained effects of EMG-triggered NMES and TENS, both combined with bilateral arm training, on hemiplegic shoulder pain and arm function in stroke patients.
results_summary: EMG-triggered NMES with bilateral arm training showed greater pain reduction and improved shoulder movement compared to TENS, with sustained benefits at follow-up. Both groups improved in pain at rest and arm function post-treatment, though resting pain improvements were not maintained.
population_specificity: Chronic and subacute stroke patients (38 participants, 25 males and 13 females, mean age 60.75 ± 10.84 years, post-stroke duration 32.68 ± 53.07 months) with hemiplegic shoulder pain.
effective_dosage: Electrical stimulation followed by bilateral arm training 3 times a week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether transcutaneous electrical sensory stimulation (TESS) without muscle contraction improves swallowing ability in dysphagia patients.
results_summary: TESS using interferential current improved airway defense (reduced cough latency time) and nutritional intake in dysphagia patients compared to sham treatment. The effects were observed after two weeks of intervention.
population_specificity: 43 elderly patients (mean age 84.3 years, 58% women) undergoing in-hospital dysphagia rehabilitation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of multichannel neuromuscular electrical stimulation (NMES) in improving gait patterns and muscle strength in children with spastic cerebral palsy.
results_summary: The study found that NMES can substantially improve gait patterns, promote muscle strength, and reduce spasticity in children with spastic CP. Patient-specific NMES protocols based on 3D gait analysis facilitated functional gait improvements, including stance-phase hip and knee extension and swing-phase hip and knee flexion.
population_specificity: Children with spastic cerebral palsy

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of NMES superimposed onto voluntary muscular contraction on cardiorespiratory performance and functionality in severe COPD patients undergoing a home-based rehabilitation program.
results_summary: The intervention group showed significant improvements in cardiorespiratory performance and functionality compared to the control group, with no significant changes observed in the control group. The between-group analysis confirmed these improvements were statistically significant.
population_specificity: 36 stable severe COPD patients.
effective_dosage: 30 minutes of NMES superimposed onto voluntary muscular contraction, 2 hours per week for 8 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether adding neuromuscular electrical stimulation therapy to standard rehabilitation improved physical and mental health-related quality of life in military service members with traumatic transtibial amputation.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in mental health-related quality of life between groups receiving neuromuscular electrical stimulation plus standard rehabilitation versus standard rehabilitation alone. Physical health-related quality of life improved over time in both groups, but the addition of neuromuscular electrical stimulation did not enhance this improvement.
population_specificity: Military service members aged 19-46 with traumatic unilateral transtibial amputation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of neuromuscular electrical stimulation (NMES) in improving functional recovery after total knee arthroplasty.
results_summary: NMES showed slightly better functional recovery compared to standard rehabilitation, particularly in the first postoperative weeks/months, with benefits diminishing over time. The most significant improvements were seen in patients with severe muscular activation deficits.
population_specificity: Patients who underwent total knee arthroplasty (496 participants across six studies).
study_duration: First postoperative weeks/months (exact duration not specified)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether neuromuscular electrical stimulation (NMES) could prevent or attenuate muscle loss during short-term disuse by augmenting muscle protein synthesis rates.
results_summary: NMES was found to augment postabsorptive and postprandial muscle protein synthesis rates, helping prevent muscle loss during disuse. Combining NMES with appropriate nutritional support further enhanced muscle preservation.
population_specificity: Otherwise healthy individuals undergoing short-term muscle disuse (e.g., due to illness, injury, or bed rest).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of NMES combined with sit-to-stand-to-sit exercises in improving quadriceps strength and lower limb symmetry after ACL reconstruction.
results_summary: NMES + STSTS participants showed greater knee extensor strength, reduced pain perception, and improved limb loading symmetry compared to STSTS-only and no additional treatment groups at 60 and 180 days post-surgery. STSTS-only participants also showed better symmetry than the control group at 60 days.
population_specificity: 63 patients recovering from anterior cruciate ligament reconstruction (ACLR).
effective_dosage: Not specified (6-week training protocol with NMES superimposed on STSTS exercises).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether combining neuromuscular electrical stimulation (NMES) with strengthening exercise improves movement in children with spastic cerebral palsy compared to NMES alone.
results_summary: The study found that NMES combined with strengthening exercise significantly reduced spasticity (CSS score), improved gross motor function (GMFM score), and increased walking speed more effectively than NMES alone at 6 weeks and 3 months post-treatment.
population_specificity: Children with spastic cerebral palsy (n = 100, divided into treatment and control groups).
study_duration: 6 weeks of intervention, with follow-up at 3 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether NMES combined with standard physical therapy is more effective than standard physical therapy alone in improving quadriceps strength and physical function after ACL surgery.
results_summary: NMES significantly improved quadriceps strength (SMD = 0.73) and physical function in the short-term (4-12 weeks) post-surgery compared to standard physical therapy alone. The PEDro scores indicated moderate methodological quality (3/10 to 7/10).
population_specificity: Patients recovering from ACL surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the treatment effects of electromyographic bridge (EMGB) versus cyclic neuromuscular electrical stimulation (NMES) on wrist and finger impairments in subacute stroke patients.
results_summary: The EMGB group showed significantly greater improvements in motor function, voluntary electromyographic ratios, and active range of motion compared to the cyclic NMES group. More participants in the EMGB group regained measurable wrist and finger movements than in the cyclic NMES group.
population_specificity: 42 hemiplegic subacute stroke patients within 6 months of their cerebrovascular accidents.
effective_dosage: 10 sessions per week of hand training with EMGB or cyclic NMES.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the feasibility of a randomized controlled trial for low-frequency electrical muscle stimulation (LF-EMS) in reducing breathlessness and improving exercise capacity in severe heart failure patients.
results_summary: The study found that LF-EMS was feasible and tolerable for severe heart failure patients, but adherence to follow-up was challenging. While there were no significant differences in 6-minute walk distance or quality of life between LF-EMS and sham groups, both outcomes showed slightly greater improvement with LF-EMS.
population_specificity: Patients with severe heart failure (NYHA class III-IV) and left ventricular ejection fraction <40%.
effective_dosage: 4 Hz, continuous stimulation for 60 minutes, 5 times per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the clinical effectiveness of high-frequency localized muscle vibration (LMV) versus neuromuscular electrical stimulation (NMES) for quadriceps strengthening in patients with knee osteoarthritis (OA).
results_summary: The study found that NMES did not produce significant improvements in clinical outcomes (e.g., pain, function, mobility) compared to LMV, which showed significant benefits. sEMG analysis suggested LMV increased type II muscle fiber involvement, but NMES did not demonstrate similar effects.
population_specificity: 30 patients aged 40–65 years with clinically diagnosed knee OA.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the skin whitening properties of Panax Ginseng (Korean Ginseng) among other vegetable oils.
results_summary: The study found that Panax Ginseng demonstrated skin whitening properties, with its activity linked to its composition. The effects were observed in vitro, suggesting potential for dermatological and cosmetic applications.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether biochar could enhance arbuscular mycorrhizal fungi (AMF) colonization in Panax quinquefolius and explore the mechanisms behind this effect.
results_summary: The study found that combining AMF with 2% biochar significantly increased AMF colonization rates and intensity, attracting beneficial microorganisms linked to secondary metabolite production, thereby improving plant quality.
population_specificity: Panax quinquefolius (American Ginseng) plants

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of Ginsenosides (derived from Panax Ginseng) on cognitive function and quality of life in stroke patients compared to other plant extracts and placebo.
results_summary: Ginsenosides were the most effective in improving Barthel Index (SUCRA 74.7%), MMSE (SUCRA 93%), and MOCA (SUCRA 79.7%) scores, indicating significant benefits for cognitive function and daily living activities in stroke patients.
population_specificity: Stroke patients (6,599 participants across 48 randomized controlled trials).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Xinyin tablets (containing Panax Ginseng) alleviate chronic heart failure (CHF) in mice and explore its mechanism of action in H9c2 cells.
results_summary: Xinyin tablets improved cardiac function, reduced apoptosis markers (caspase-3, caspase-9, Bax), and enhanced mitophagy via the HDAC3-mediated PINK1/Parkin pathway in both mice and H9c2 cells.
population_specificity: SPF C57 mice and H9c2 cardiomyocytes.
effective_dosage: Low-, medium-, and high-dose Xinyin tablets (specific amounts not provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the anti-tumor efficacy of a ginseng-derived exosome (G-Exo)-based cisplatin (CDDP) delivery system (G-CDDP) in vitro and in vivo.
results_summary: G-CDDP effectively targeted tumor sites, inhibited proliferation and migration, and promoted apoptosis in U-87MG tumor cells, requiring 12.66 times less CDDP than free CDDP for the same cytotoxic effect. In tumor-bearing mice, G-CDDP showed significant therapeutic effects.
population_specificity: U-87MG tumor cells and U-87MG tumor-bearing mice.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of Panax Ginseng (Korean Ginseng) and its compounds, particularly ginsenosides, in treating colorectal cancer (CRC) through mechanisms like apoptosis induction, immune response enhancement, and drug carrier utilization.
results_summary: The study found that Panax Ginseng extracts and specific ginsenosides (Rh2, Rg3, Rb1, Rb2) reduced CRC cell proliferation and tumor size in a mouse model, modulated gut microbiota to enhance immune response, and improved drug efficacy when used in nanocarriers.
population_specificity: CRC cells (in vitro) and a xenograft mouse model (in vivo).
